title.zh: 《淮陰侯列傳》 Biography of the Marquis of Huaiyin
title.raw: 《淮陰侯列傳》 Biography of the Marquis of Huaiyin

sentences.zh: 淮陰侯韓信者，淮陰人也。

translations.literal: The Marquis of Huaiyin Han Xin was a man of Huaiyin.
translations.idiomatic: Han Xin, Marquis of Huaiyin, was a man of Huaiyin.

sentences.zh: 始為布衣時，貧無行，不得推擇為吏，又不能治生商賈，常從人寄食飲，人多厭之者，常數從其下鄉南昌亭長寄食，數月，亭長妻患之，乃晨炊蓐食。

translations.literal: When he first wore commoner's clothes, he was poor and without proper conduct, could not be recommended for official position, and could not manage a livelihood through business or trade; he constantly depended on others for food and drink, and many people disliked him; he often went to the Nanchang pavilion chief below his village to beg for food, and after several months, the pavilion chief's wife was annoyed by it, so she cooked early and ate in bed.
translations.idiomatic: When he first lived as a commoner, he was poor and lacked proper conduct. He could not be recommended for an official position and could not make a living through business or trade. He constantly depended on others for food and drink, and many people disliked him. He often went to the pavilion chief of Nanchang village below his own to beg for food. After several months, the pavilion chief's wife was annoyed by this, so she cooked early and ate in bed.

sentences.zh: 食時信往，不為具食。

translations.literal: When mealtime came, Xin went there, but she did not prepare food for him.
translations.idiomatic: When mealtime came, Xin went there, but she did not prepare food for him.

sentences.zh: 信亦知其意，怒，竟絕去。

translations.literal: Xin also understood her intention, became angry, and finally left forever.
translations.idiomatic: Xin also understood her intention. He became angry and finally left forever.

sentences.zh: 信釣於城下，諸母漂，有一母見信饑，飯信，竟漂數十日。

translations.literal: Xin fished below the city walls, and there were washerwomen rinsing clothes; one washerwoman saw that Xin was hungry and fed him, and for dozens of days she continued rinsing clothes.
translations.idiomatic: Xin fished below the city walls. There were washerwomen rinsing clothes. One washerwoman saw that Xin was hungry and fed him. For dozens of days, she continued rinsing clothes.

sentences.zh: 信喜，謂漂母曰：「吾必有以重報母。

translations.literal: Xin was pleased, and said to the washerwoman: 'I will certainly repay Mother handsomely.
translations.idiomatic: Xin was delighted and said to the washerwoman: 'I will certainly repay you handsomely.

sentences.zh: 」母怒曰：「大丈夫不能自食，吾哀王孫而進食，豈望報乎！」

translations.literal: ' The mother became angry and said: 'A great man cannot feed himself, I pitied the young noble and gave him food, did I expect repayment?'
translations.idiomatic: ' The washerwoman grew angry and said: 'A grown man who can't feed himself—I pitied this young gentleman and gave him food. Did I expect anything in return?'

sentences.zh: 淮陰屠中少年有侮信者，曰：「若雖長大，好帶刀劍，中情怯耳。

translations.literal: Among the young butchers of Huaiyin there was one who insulted Xin, saying: 'Though you are tall and big, you like to wear swords, but in your heart you're cowardly.
translations.idiomatic: Among the young butchers in Huaiyin was one who humiliated Xin, saying: 'You're big and tall, you like strapping on swords, but deep down you're just a coward.

sentences.zh: 」眾辱之曰：「信能死，刺我；

translations.literal: ' The crowd humiliated him, saying: 'If Xin dares die, stab me;
translations.idiomatic: ' The crowd jeered at him: 'If Xin has the guts to die, then stab me;

sentences.zh: 不能死，出我袴下。

translations.literal: if he cannot die, crawl out from between my legs.'
translations.idiomatic: if you don't have the courage to die, then crawl between my legs.'

sentences.zh: 」於是信孰視之，俛出袴下，蒲伏。

translations.literal: ' Thereupon Xin stared at him intently, bent down and crawled out from between his legs, and lay prostrate.
translations.idiomatic: ' Thereupon Xin stared at him intently, bent down and crawled out from between his legs, and lay prostrate.

sentences.zh: 一市人皆笑信，以為怯。

translations.literal: All the people in the market laughed at Xin, considering him cowardly.
translations.idiomatic: Everyone in the market laughed at Xin, taking him for a coward.

sentences.zh: 及項梁渡淮，信杖劍從之，居戲下，無所知名。

translations.literal: When Xiang Liang crossed the Huai, Xin took up sword and staff to follow him, dwelt under Xi, and was not known anywhere.
translations.idiomatic: When Xiang Liang crossed the Huai, Xin took up sword and staff to follow him. He dwelt under Xi and was not known anywhere.

sentences.zh: 項梁敗，又屬項羽，羽以為郎中。

translations.literal: Xiang Liang was defeated, and he again attached himself to Xiang Yu, who made him a palace attendant.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Liang was defeated, and Xin again attached himself to Xiang Yu, who made him a palace attendant.

sentences.zh: 數以策干項羽，羽不用。

translations.literal: He repeatedly presented strategies to Xiang Yu, but Yu did not use them.
translations.idiomatic: He repeatedly presented strategies to Xiang Yu, but Yu did not use them.

sentences.zh: 漢王之入蜀，信亡楚歸漢，未得知名，為連敖。

translations.literal: When the Han king entered Shu, Xin fled Chu to return to Han, had not yet gained fame, and became a lian'ao.
translations.idiomatic: When the Han king entered Shu, Xin fled Chu to return to Han. He had not yet gained fame and became a lian'ao.

sentences.zh: 坐法當斬，其輩十三人皆已斬，次至信，信乃仰視，適見滕公，曰：「上不欲就天下乎？

translations.literal: He sat condemned by law to beheading. His group of thirteen men had all been beheaded. It came to Xin's turn. Xin then looked up and happened to see Duke Teng, saying: 'Does Your Majesty not wish to gain the world?
translations.idiomatic: He was condemned by law to beheading. His group of thirteen men had all been executed. When it came to Xin's turn, he looked up and caught sight of Duke Teng, saying: 'Doesn't Your Majesty want to win the empire?

sentences.zh: 何為斬壯士！

translations.literal: Why execute a valiant warrior!'
translations.idiomatic: Why execute a capable man!'

sentences.zh: 」滕公奇其言，壯其貌，釋而不斬。

translations.literal: ' Duke Teng was amazed by his words, admired his appearance, released him and did not execute him.
translations.idiomatic: ' Duke Teng was amazed by his words and admired his bearing. He released him without executing him.

sentences.zh: 與語，大說之。

translations.literal: He spoke with him and was greatly pleased.
translations.idiomatic: He spoke with him and was greatly pleased.

sentences.zh: 言於上，上拜以為治粟都尉，上未之奇也。

translations.literal: He spoke to the emperor, who appointed him as Colonel of Grain Regulation. The emperor did not yet consider him extraordinary.
translations.idiomatic: He spoke to the emperor, who appointed him as Colonel of Grain Regulation. The emperor did not yet consider him extraordinary.

sentences.zh: 信數與蕭何語，何奇之。

translations.literal: Xin frequently spoke with Xiao He, who considered him extraordinary.
translations.idiomatic: Xin frequently spoke with Xiao He, who considered him extraordinary.

sentences.zh: 至南鄭，諸將行道亡者數十人，信度何等已數言上，上不我用，即亡。

translations.literal: Upon arriving at Nanzheng, dozens of generals fled along the way. Xin estimated that Xiao He and others had already spoken to the emperor several times. Since the emperor would not use him, he fled.
translations.idiomatic: When they reached Nanzheng, dozens of generals deserted along the way. Xin figured that Xiao He and the others must have spoken to the emperor about him multiple times already. Since the emperor wasn't going to use him, he deserted too.

sentences.zh: 何聞信亡，不及以聞，自追之。

translations.literal: When Xiao He heard that Xin had fled, without having time to report it, he personally pursued him.
translations.idiomatic: When Xiao He heard Xin had fled, he didn't even take time to report it—he went after him himself.

sentences.zh: 人有言上曰：「丞相何亡。

translations.literal: Someone spoke to the emperor, saying: 'The Chancellor Xiao He has fled.'
translations.idiomatic: Someone told the emperor: 'Chancellor Xiao He has deserted.'

sentences.zh: 」上大怒，如失左右手。

translations.literal: ' The emperor was greatly angered, as if he had lost his left and right hands.
translations.idiomatic: ' The emperor flew into a rage, as if he'd lost both his hands.

sentences.zh: 居一二日，何來謁上，上且怒且喜，罵何曰：「若亡，何也？

translations.literal: After one or two days, Xiao He came to pay respects to the emperor. The emperor was both angry and pleased, cursing Xiao He, saying: 'You fled, didn't you?
translations.idiomatic: After a day or two, Xiao He came to see the emperor. The emperor was both angry and relieved, cursing Xiao He: 'You deserted, didn't you?

sentences.zh: 」何曰：「臣不敢亡也，臣追亡者。

translations.literal: ' Xiao He said: 'This minister did not dare flee. This minister was pursuing a fugitive.
translations.idiomatic: ' Xiao He said: 'I didn't dare desert. I was chasing a fugitive.

sentences.zh: 」上曰：「若所追者誰何？

translations.literal: ' The emperor said: 'Who was it you were pursuing?
translations.idiomatic: ' The emperor said: 'Who were you chasing?

sentences.zh: 」曰：「韓信也。

translations.literal: ' Said: 'Han Xin.'
translations.idiomatic: ' Han Xin.'

sentences.zh: 」上復罵曰：「諸將亡者以十數，公無所追；

translations.literal: ' The emperor cursed again, saying: 'The other generals who fled numbered in the dozens, yet you pursued none of them;
translations.idiomatic: ' The emperor cursed again: 'Dozens of generals deserted, but you didn't chase a single one;

sentences.zh: 追信，詐也。

translations.literal: pursuing Xin—that's just deception.'
translations.idiomatic: going after Xin is just a pretense.'

sentences.zh: 」何曰：「諸將易得耳。

translations.literal: ' Xiao He said: 'Other generals are easily obtained.
translations.idiomatic: ' Xiao He said: 'Other generals are easy to find.

sentences.zh: 至如信者，國士無雙。

translations.literal: As for someone like Xin, he is a peerless warrior of the realm.
translations.idiomatic: A man like Xin is unmatched among the warriors of the realm.

sentences.zh: 王必欲長王漢中，無所事信；

translations.literal: If Your Majesty wishes to rule only Hanzhong for a long time, there is no need to employ Xin;
translations.idiomatic: If Your Majesty just wants to rule Hanzhong permanently, you have no need for Xin;

sentences.zh: 必欲爭天下，非信無所與計事者。

translations.literal: but if Your Majesty wishes to contend for the world, there is no one else with whom to plan affairs except Xin.'
translations.idiomatic: but if Your Majesty wants to vie for the world, there's no one else you can consult with except Xin.'

sentences.zh: 顧王策安所決耳。

translations.literal: But the king's plan—what decision has it reached?
translations.idiomatic: But what decision has Your Majesty reached about your plans?

sentences.zh: 」王曰：「吾亦欲東耳，安能郁郁久居此乎？

translations.literal: ' The king said: 'I also wish to go east. How can I remain here depressed for long?
translations.idiomatic: ' The king said: 'I want to march east too. How can I stay cooped up here forever?

sentences.zh: 」何曰：「王計必欲東，能用信，信即留；

translations.literal: ' Xiao He said: 'Your Majesty's plans certainly wish to go east. If you can employ Xin, Xin will stay;
translations.idiomatic: ' Xiao He said: 'Your Majesty is definitely planning to march east. If you use Xin, he'll stay;

sentences.zh: 不能用，信終亡耳。

translations.literal: if you cannot employ him, Xin will ultimately desert.'
translations.idiomatic: if you can't use him, Xin will desert for good.'

sentences.zh: 」王曰：「吾為公以為將。

translations.literal: ' The king said: 'For your sake, I will appoint him as a general.'
translations.idiomatic: ' The king said: 'For your sake, I'll make him a general.'

sentences.zh: 」何曰：「雖為將，信必不留。

translations.literal: ' Xiao He said: 'Even if appointed as general, Xin will certainly not stay.'
translations.idiomatic: ' Xiao He said: 'Even as a general, Xin definitely won't stay.'

sentences.zh: 」王曰：「以為大將。

translations.literal: ' The king said: 'I will appoint him as Grand General.'
translations.idiomatic: ' The king said: 'I'll make him Supreme Commander.'

sentences.zh: 」何曰：「幸甚。

translations.literal: ' Xiao He said: 'That would be most fortunate.'
translations.idiomatic: ' Xiao He said: 'That's perfect.'

sentences.zh: 」於是王欲召信拜之。

translations.literal: ' Thereupon the king wished to summon Xin and enfeoff him.
translations.idiomatic: ' Thereupon the king decided to summon Xin and grant him a command.

sentences.zh: 何曰：「王素慢無禮，今拜大將如呼小兒耳，此乃信所以去也。

translations.literal: Xiao He said: 'Your Majesty has always been arrogant and disrespectful. Now appointing the Grand General is like calling a child—this is why Xin left.
translations.idiomatic: Xiao He said: 'Your Majesty has always been arrogant and rude. Appointing the Grand General now is like calling over a child—this is why Xin deserted.

sentences.zh: 王必欲拜之，擇良日，齋戒，設壇場，具禮，乃可耳。

translations.literal: If Your Majesty truly wishes to appoint him, choose an auspicious day, fast and purify yourself, set up an altar platform, prepare the full rites, then it will be acceptable.'
translations.idiomatic: If Your Majesty really wants to appoint him, pick an auspicious day, fast and purify yourself, set up a ceremonial altar, and perform all the proper rites. Only then will it work.'

sentences.zh: 」王許之。

translations.literal: ' The king permitted it.
translations.idiomatic: ' The king agreed.

sentences.zh: 諸將皆喜，人人各自以為得大將。

translations.literal: All the generals were pleased, each thinking he himself would get the Grand General position.
translations.idiomatic: All the generals were delighted, each one thinking he would be appointed Grand General.

sentences.zh: 至拜大將，乃韓信也，一軍皆驚。

translations.literal: When it came to enfeoffing the Grand General, it was Han Xin—the entire army was astonished.
translations.idiomatic: When the time came to appoint the Grand General, it turned out to be Han Xin—the whole army was stunned.

sentences.zh: 信拜禮畢，上坐。

translations.literal: Xin completed the enfeoffment rites and sat above.
translations.idiomatic: Xin finished the investiture ceremony and took the seat of honor.

sentences.zh: 王曰：「丞相數言將軍，將軍何以教寡人計策？

translations.literal: The king said: 'The Chancellor has repeatedly spoken of the General; General, what strategy will you teach me?
translations.idiomatic: The king said: 'The Chancellor has spoken of you many times, General. What strategy will you teach me?

sentences.zh: 」信謝，因問王曰：「今東鄉爭權天下，豈非項王邪？

translations.literal: ' Xin thanked him, then asked the king: 'Now facing east to contend for the world's authority, is it not King Xiang?
translations.idiomatic: ' Xin expressed thanks, then asked the king: 'Now that we're marching east to vie for control of the world, isn't it King Xiang we're up against?

sentences.zh: 」漢王曰：「然。

translations.literal: ' The Han king said: 'Yes.
translations.idiomatic: ' The Han king said: 'Indeed.

sentences.zh: 」曰：「大王自料勇悍仁彊孰與項王？

translations.literal: ' Said: 'Your Majesty, assess for yourself: in courage, fierceness, benevolence, and strength, how do you compare to King Xiang?
translations.idiomatic: ' He said: 'Your Majesty, compare yourself to King Xiang: in courage, ferocity, benevolence, and power, who is superior?

sentences.zh: 」漢王默然良久，曰：「不如也。

translations.literal: ' The Han king was silent for a long time, then said: 'I am inferior.
translations.idiomatic: ' The Han king fell silent for a long while, then said: 'I am not as good.'

sentences.zh: 」信再拜賀曰：「惟信亦為大王不如也。

translations.literal: ' Xin bowed twice and congratulated him, saying: 'Even I, Xin, am also inferior to Your Majesty.
translations.idiomatic: ' Xin bowed twice in congratulations and said: 'Even I, Xin, admit I'm inferior to Your Majesty.

sentences.zh: 然臣嘗事之，請言項王之為人也。

translations.literal: Yet I have served him; allow me to speak of King Xiang's character.
translations.idiomatic: Nevertheless, I once served under him. Allow me to describe King Xiang's character.

sentences.zh: 項王喑噁叱，千人皆廢，然不能任屬賢將，此特匹夫之勇耳。

translations.literal: King Xiang roars with rage and glares, a thousand men all collapse, yet he cannot appoint and employ worthy generals—this is merely the courage of a common man.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang bellows in fury and glares fiercely—thousands of men crumple in terror. Yet he cannot bring himself to appoint and employ capable generals. This is nothing but the bravery of a common thug.

sentences.zh: 項王見人恭敬慈愛，言語嘔嘔，人有疾病，涕泣分食飲，至使人有功當封爵者，印刓敝，忍不能予，此所謂婦人之仁也。

translations.literal: King Xiang sees people with courtesy and kindness, speaks gently and tenderly; when people are ill, he weeps and shares his food and drink; but when it comes to those who have merit and should be enfeoffed with rank, the seals are worn and broken, he cannot bear to give them—this is what is called womanly benevolence.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang treats people with polite kindness and speaks in gentle murmurs. When someone falls ill, he weeps and shares his own food and drink with them. But when it comes to rewarding those who deserve rank and fiefs, his seals sit worn and broken—he can't bring himself to hand them out. This is what's called womanly compassion.

sentences.zh: 項王雖霸天下而臣諸侯，不居關中而都彭城。

translations.literal: Although King Xiang hegemonized the world and made the feudal lords his subjects, he did not reside in Guanzhong but made Pengcheng his capital.
translations.idiomatic: Although King Xiang became hegemon over the world and made the feudal lords his vassals, he refused to establish his capital in Guanzhong, choosing Pengcheng instead.

sentences.zh: 有背義帝之約，而以親愛王，諸侯不平。

translations.literal: He violated the agreement with the Righteous Emperor and instead enfeoffed his close relatives and favorites. The feudal lords were dissatisfied.
translations.idiomatic: He broke his agreement with the Righteous Emperor and instead enfeoffed his relatives and favorites as kings. The other lords were outraged.

sentences.zh: 諸侯之見項王遷逐義帝置江南，亦皆歸逐其主而自王善地。

translations.literal: When the feudal lords saw King Xiang move and expel the Righteous Emperor to place him in Jiangnan, they also returned to expel their own lords and established themselves as kings in good territories.
translations.idiomatic: When the other lords saw King Xiang relocate and exile the Righteous Emperor to Jiangnan, they went home and drove out their own rulers, crowning themselves kings in choice territories.

sentences.zh: 項王所過無不殘滅者，天下多怨，百姓不親附，特劫於威彊耳。

translations.literal: Wherever King Xiang passed, he left nothing undestroyed. The world harbored much resentment. The common people did not closely attach themselves to him; they were merely coerced by his powerful might.
translations.idiomatic: Wherever King Xiang went, he left nothing but devastation. The whole world seethed with resentment. The people didn't rally to him willingly—they were just intimidated by his overwhelming power.

sentences.zh: 名雖為霸，實失天下心。

translations.literal: Although in name he was a hegemon, in reality he lost the hearts of the world.
translations.idiomatic: Though he bore the title of hegemon, he had in truth forfeited the allegiance of all under heaven.

sentences.zh: 故曰其彊易弱。

translations.literal: Therefore it is said that his strength easily became weakness.
translations.idiomatic: That's why they say his strength quickly turned to weakness.

sentences.zh: 今大王誠能反其道：任天下武勇，何所不誅！

translations.literal: Now if Your Majesty can sincerely reverse this way: employ the world's martial braves, what cannot be executed!
translations.idiomatic: Now if Your Majesty can truly do the opposite: employ all the world's brave warriors, there will be nothing you cannot conquer!

sentences.zh: 以天下城邑封功臣，何所不服！

translations.literal: Enfeoff meritorious officials with the world's cities and towns, what cannot be made submissive!
translations.idiomatic: Enfeoff your meritorious officials with cities across the empire, and there will be nothing you cannot bring under control!

sentences.zh: 以義兵從思東歸之士，何所不散！

translations.literal: Lead with righteous troops following soldiers who long to return east, what cannot be scattered!
translations.idiomatic: Lead with armies fighting for justice, following troops who yearn to return home—what force cannot be routed!

sentences.zh: 且三秦王為秦將，將秦子弟數歲矣，所殺亡不可勝計，又欺其眾降諸侯，至新安，項王詐阬秦降卒二十餘萬，唯獨邯、欣、翳得脫，秦父兄怨此三人，痛入骨髓。

translations.literal: Moreover, the three kings of Qin served as Qin generals and led Qin youths for several years. The number they killed and caused to perish cannot be counted. They also deceived their troops into surrendering to the feudal lords. At Xin'an, King Xiang deceitfully pit-killed over 200,000 Qin surrendering troops. Only Han, Xin, and Yi escaped alone. The Qin fathers and elder brothers resent these three men, their pain entering their very bone marrow.
translations.idiomatic: Furthermore, the three kings of Qin served as generals for Qin and led Qin youths for several years. The dead and perished under their command are beyond counting. They tricked their troops into surrendering to the other lords. At Xin'an, King Xiang deceitfully massacred more than 200,000 surrendering Qin troops in pits. Only Han, Xin, and Yi got away. The fathers and brothers of Qin hate these three men with a bitterness that cuts to the bone.

sentences.zh: 今楚彊以威王此三人，秦民莫愛也。

translations.literal: Now Chu uses might to establish these three as kings. The Qin people love none of them.
translations.idiomatic: Now Chu is forcing these three men on Qin as kings by sheer power. Not a single Qin subject loves them.

sentences.zh: 大王之入武關，秋豪無所害，除秦苛法，與秦民約，法三章耳，秦民無不欲得大王王秦者。

translations.literal: When Your Majesty entered Wuguan, not even an autumn hair was harmed. You removed Qin's harsh laws and made an agreement with the Qin people—only three chapters of law. There is no Qin person who does not desire Your Majesty to be king of Qin.
translations.idiomatic: When Your Majesty entered Wuguan Pass, you didn't harm so much as a hair. You abolished Qin's cruel laws and made a simple covenant with the Qin people—just three articles of law. Every single Qin subject wants you to be their king.

sentences.zh: 於諸侯之約，大王當王關中，關中民咸知之。

translations.literal: According to the agreement among the feudal lords, Your Majesty should be king of Guanzhong. All the people of Guanzhong know this.
translations.idiomatic: By the covenant among the lords, Your Majesty was supposed to rule Guanzhong. Every soul in Guanzhong knows this.

sentences.zh: 大王失職入漢中，秦民無不恨者。

translations.literal: Your Majesty lost your rightful position and entered Hanzhong. There is no Qin person who does not resent this.
translations.idiomatic: Your Majesty was robbed of your rightful domain and forced into Hanzhong. Not a single Qin subject doesn't bitterly resent this.

sentences.zh: 今大王舉而東，三秦可傳檄而定也。

translations.literal: Now if Your Majesty raises troops and goes east, the three Qin regions can be settled by sending dispatches.
translations.idiomatic: Now if Your Majesty marches east with your armies, the three Qin territories can be pacified with just a few written commands.

sentences.zh: 」於是漢王大喜，自以為得信晚。

translations.literal: ' Thereupon the Han king was greatly pleased, considering that he had obtained Xin too late.
translations.idiomatic: ' Thereupon the Han king was overjoyed, thinking he had found Xin far too late.

sentences.zh: 遂聽信計，部署諸將所擊。

translations.literal: He then followed Xin's plan and deployed the various generals to their attack positions.
translations.idiomatic: He adopted Xin's strategy and assigned each general his target.

sentences.zh: 八月，漢王舉兵東出陳倉，定三秦。

translations.literal: In the eighth month, the Han king raised troops and went east from Chencang, pacifying the three Qin regions.
translations.idiomatic: In the eighth month, the Han king mobilized his forces and marched east from Chencang to pacify the three Qin territories.

sentences.zh: 漢二年，出關，收魏、河南，韓、殷王皆降。

translations.literal: In the second year of Han, he exited the pass and gathered Wei and Henan. The kings of Han and Yin all surrendered.
translations.idiomatic: In Han's second year, he emerged from the pass and took Wei and Henan. The kings of Han and Yin both submitted.

sentences.zh: 合齊、趙共擊楚。

translations.literal: He combined with Qi and Zhao to attack Chu together.
translations.idiomatic: He allied with Qi and Zhao to launch a joint assault on Chu.

sentences.zh: 四月，至彭城，漢兵敗散而還。

translations.literal: In the fourth month, they reached Pengcheng. The Han troops were defeated and scattered, returning home.
translations.idiomatic: In the fourth month, they reached Pengcheng. The Han army was routed and fled home in disarray.

sentences.zh: 信復收兵與漢王會滎陽，復擊破楚京、索之閒，以故楚兵卒不能西。

translations.literal: Xin again gathered troops and met the Han king at Xingyang. He again attacked and defeated Chu between Jing and Suo. Because of this, Chu troops ultimately could not advance west.
translations.idiomatic: Xin regrouped his forces and rendezvoused with the Han king at Xingyang. He struck again and crushed Chu forces between Jing and Suo. This prevented the Chu army from advancing west.

sentences.zh: 漢之敗卻彭城，塞王欣、翟王翳亡漢降楚，齊、趙亦反漢與楚和。

translations.literal: After Han's defeat and retreat from Pengcheng, King Sai Xin and King Dai Yi fled Han and surrendered to Chu. Qi and Zhao also rebelled against Han and allied with Chu.
translations.idiomatic: After Han's rout at Pengcheng, King Sai Xin and King Dai Yi deserted to Chu. Qi and Zhao also turned against Han and allied with Chu.

sentences.zh: 六月，魏王豹謁歸視親疾，至國，即絕河關反漢，與楚約和。

translations.literal: In the sixth month, King Wei Bao took leave to return and see his relative's illness. Upon arriving in his state, he immediately cut off the river passes and rebelled against Han, making an alliance agreement with Chu.
translations.idiomatic: In the sixth month, King Wei Bao requested leave to visit a sick relative. Once back in his domain, he sealed the river crossings and rebelled against Han, forging an alliance with Chu.

sentences.zh: 漢王使酈生說豹，不下。

translations.literal: The Han king sent Li Sheng to persuade Bao, but he did not submit.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king dispatched Li Yiji to talk Bao around, but he refused to yield.

sentences.zh: 其八月，以信為左丞相，擊魏。

translations.literal: In that eighth month, Xin was appointed Left Prime Minister and attacked Wei.
translations.idiomatic: That eighth month, Xin was named Left Prime Minister and sent to attack Wei.

sentences.zh: 魏王盛兵蒲阪，塞臨晉，信乃益為疑兵，陳船欲度臨晉，而伏兵從夏陽以木罌缻渡軍，襲安邑。

translations.literal: The King of Wei amassed troops at Puban and blocked Linjin. Xin then created additional feigned troops, arraying ships as if he wished to cross at Linjin, while his ambush troops crossed the army from Xiayang using wooden jars and pots, attacking Anyi by surprise.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Wei massed troops at Puban and fortified Linjin. Xin created decoy forces, lining up ships as if to cross at Linjin, while his hidden troops ferried across from Xiayang using wooden floats and barrels to ambush Anyi.

sentences.zh: 魏王豹驚，引兵迎信，信遂虜豹，定魏為河東郡。

translations.literal: King Wei Bao was alarmed and led troops to meet Xin. Xin then captured Bao and pacified Wei, establishing it as Hedong commandery.
translations.idiomatic: King Wei Bao panicked and marched out to confront Xin. Xin captured him and pacified Wei, reorganizing it as Hedong commandery.

sentences.zh: 漢王遣張耳與信俱，引兵東，北擊趙、代。

translations.literal: The Han king sent Zhang Er together with Xin. They led troops east and north to attack Zhao and Dai.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king dispatched Zhang Er to join Xin. They marched east then north to strike at Zhao and Dai.

sentences.zh: 後九月，破代兵，禽夏說閼與。

translations.literal: In the following ninth month, they defeated Dai troops and captured Xia Yue at Yanmen.
translations.idiomatic: The following ninth month, they crushed Dai forces and took Xia Yue prisoner at Yanmen.

sentences.zh: 信之下魏破代，漢輒使人收其精兵，詣滎陽以距楚。

translations.literal: Whenever Xin conquered Wei or defeated Dai, Han would send people to withdraw his elite troops and send them to Xingyang to resist Chu.
translations.idiomatic: Every time Xin conquered Wei or defeated Dai, Han would immediately withdraw his best troops and send them to Xingyang to hold off Chu.

sentences.zh: 信與張耳以兵數萬，欲東下井陘擊趙。

translations.literal: Xin and Zhang Er, with several tens of thousands of troops, wished to go east down through Jingxing to attack Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: Xin and Zhang Er, commanding tens of thousands of troops, planned to march east through Jingxing Pass to attack Zhao.

sentences.zh: 趙王、成安君陳餘聞漢且襲之也，聚兵井陘口，號稱二十萬。

translations.literal: The King of Zhao and Lord Cheng'an Chen Yu heard that Han was about to attack them by surprise, and gathered troops at the Jingxing pass mouth, claiming 200,000 in number.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Zhao and Lord Cheng'an Chen Yu heard Han was about to ambush them, so they massed troops at the mouth of Jingxing Pass, boasting an army of 200,000.

sentences.zh: 廣武君李左車說成安君曰：「聞漢將韓信涉西河，虜魏王，禽夏說，新喋血閼與，今乃輔以張耳，議欲下趙，此乘勝而去國遠鬬，其鋒不可當。

translations.literal: Lord Guangwu Li Zuoche advised Lord Cheng'an, saying: 'I hear that the Han general Han Xin forded the Xishui, captured the King of Wei, seized Xia Yue, and recently bloodied Yanmen. Now he is assisted by Zhang Er and plans to conquer Zhao. This is riding victory to leave his home country for distant battle—his sharpness cannot be withstood.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Guangwu Li Zuoche counseled Lord Cheng'an: 'I've heard that Han general Han Xin crossed the Yellow River, captured the King of Wei, seized Xia Yue, and recently drenched Yanmen in blood. Now backed by Zhang Er, he plans to take Zhao. This is pressing his advantage to fight far from home—his momentum is unstoppable.

sentences.zh: 臣聞千里餽糧，士有饑色，樵蘇後爨，師不宿飽。

translations.literal: I have heard that transporting grain a thousand li, the soldiers have hungry faces; gathering firewood after cooking, the army is not sated overnight.
translations.idiomatic: I've heard that when transporting grain a thousand li, soldiers go hungry; when foraging for fuel after cooking, the army never eats its fill.

sentences.zh: 今井陘之道，車不得方軌，騎不得成列，行數百里，其勢糧食必在其後。

translations.literal: Now the Jingxing road: chariots cannot travel abreast, cavalry cannot form ranks. Marching several hundred li, their grain supplies must necessarily follow behind.
translations.idiomatic: Now the Jingxing road is so narrow that chariots can't travel side by side and cavalry can't form proper lines. Marching hundreds of li, their supplies must trail far behind.

sentences.zh: 願足下假臣奇兵三萬人，從閒道絕其輜重；

translations.literal: I wish Your Lordship would lend me 30,000 surprise troops, to go by side paths and cut off their baggage train;
translations.idiomatic: I request that Your Lordship give me 30,000 elite troops to take a roundabout route and sever their supply lines;

sentences.zh: 足下深溝高壘，堅營勿與戰。

translations.literal: Your Lordship should dig deep moats and high ramparts, strengthen the camp and do not engage in battle.
translations.idiomatic: Your Lordship should fortify with deep trenches and high walls, reinforce the camp, and avoid battle.

sentences.zh: 彼前不得鬬，退不得還，吾奇兵絕其後，使野無所掠，不至十日，而兩將之頭可致於戲下。

translations.literal: They cannot advance to fight, cannot retreat to return. Our surprise troops cut off their rear, making the fields have nothing to plunder. In not more than ten days, the two generals' heads can be brought to Your Lordship's tent.
translations.idiomatic: They won't be able to advance to fight or retreat to safety. Our elite troops will cut off their rear, leaving them nothing to forage. Within ten days, the heads of both generals will be delivered to Your Lordship.

sentences.zh: 願君留意臣之計。

translations.literal: I wish My Lord would pay attention to my plan.
translations.idiomatic: I beg My Lord to give serious consideration to my strategy.

sentences.zh: 否，必為二子所禽矣。

translations.literal: If not, you will certainly be captured by those two men.
translations.idiomatic: If not, those two generals will certainly capture you.

sentences.zh: 」成安君，儒者也，常稱義兵不用詐謀奇計，曰：「吾聞兵法十則圍之，倍則戰。

translations.literal: ' Lord Cheng'an was a Confucian scholar. He always maintained that righteous armies do not use deceitful schemes and extraordinary stratagems, saying: 'I have heard that in military law, when ten times stronger, surround them; when double, fight.
translations.idiomatic: ' Lord Cheng'an was a Confucian gentleman. He always insisted that honorable armies don't employ trickery or clever ruses, declaring: 'I've heard that according to military doctrine, surround when ten times stronger, fight when double the strength.

sentences.zh: 今韓信兵號數萬，其實不過數千。

translations.literal: Now Han Xin's troops are numbered in tens of thousands, but in reality they are no more than several thousand.
translations.idiomatic: Now Han Xin's army claims tens of thousands, but in truth it's barely several thousand.

sentences.zh: 能千里而襲我，亦已罷極。

translations.literal: Able to travel a thousand li to attack us, they are already extremely exhausted.
translations.idiomatic: Even traveling a thousand li to ambush us, they must be utterly spent.

sentences.zh: 今如此避而不擊，後有大者，何以加之！

translations.literal: Now if we thus avoid and do not attack, if later there are greater ones, what can we add to this!
translations.idiomatic: Now if we avoid fighting like this, what will we do when even greater threats come later!

sentences.zh: 則諸侯謂吾怯，而輕來伐我。

translations.literal: then the feudal lords will call us cowardly, and lightly come to attack us.
translations.idiomatic: then the other lords will think us cowards and come attack us without fear.

sentences.zh: 」不聽廣武君策，廣武君策不用。

translations.literal: ' He did not listen to Lord Guangwu's plan. Lord Guangwu's plan was not used.
translations.idiomatic: ' He rejected Lord Guangwu's strategy. Lord Guangwu's advice went unheeded.

sentences.zh: 韓信使人閒視，知其不用，還報，則大喜，乃敢引兵遂下。

translations.literal: Han Xin sent men to secretly observe, learned that they had not used it, returned and reported, then was greatly pleased, and dared to lead his troops and advance.
translations.idiomatic: Han Xin sent scouts to spy secretly. When they reported that Chen Yu had rejected Li Zuoche's advice, Xin was overjoyed and boldly marched his army forward.

sentences.zh: 未至井陘口三十里，止舍。

translations.literal: Before reaching thirty li from the Jingxing pass mouth, they stopped and camped.
translations.idiomatic: Thirty li from the mouth of Jingxing Pass, they halted and made camp.

sentences.zh: 夜半傳發，選輕騎二千人，人持一赤幟，從閒道萆山而望趙軍，誡曰：「趙見我走，必空壁逐我，若疾入趙壁，拔趙幟，立漢赤幟。

translations.literal: At midnight they transmitted orders to move out. He selected 2,000 light cavalry, each man holding one red banner, to go by side paths and climb Mount Bai to overlook the Zhao army. He instructed them: 'When Zhao sees us flee, they will certainly empty their camp and pursue us. If you quickly enter Zhao's camp, pull down Zhao's banners, and raise Han's red banners.
translations.idiomatic: At midnight, orders were passed to advance. Xin selected 2,000 light cavalry, each carrying a red banner, to take a roundabout path up Mount Bai overlooking the Zhao army. He instructed: 'When Zhao sees us retreat, they'll abandon their camp to chase us. Rush in quickly, tear down their banners, and raise our Han red flags.

sentences.zh: 」令其裨將傳飱，曰：「今日破趙會食！

translations.literal: ' He ordered his deputy generals to pass around food, saying: 'Today we will defeat Zhao and then gather to eat!
translations.idiomatic: ' He commanded his lieutenants to distribute rations, declaring: 'Today we'll crush Zhao and dine together!

sentences.zh: 」諸將皆莫信，詳應曰：「諾。

translations.literal: ' All the generals did not believe him, but pretended to respond saying: 'Yes.
translations.idiomatic: ' None of the generals believed him, but they pretended to agree: 'Very well.

sentences.zh: 」謂軍吏曰：「趙已先據便地為壁，且彼未見吾大將旗鼓，未肯擊前行，恐吾至阻險而還。

translations.literal: ' He said to the army officers: 'Zhao has already occupied advantageous ground and made fortifications. Moreover, they have not yet seen our supreme commander's banners and drums, so they will not dare attack our vanguard, fearing we will reach the dangerous terrain and turn back.
translations.idiomatic: ' He told his officers: 'Zhao already holds the high ground with fortifications. Besides, they haven't seen our commander's banners yet, so they won't attack our advance guard—they're afraid we'll reach the dangerous pass and retreat.

sentences.zh: 」信乃使萬人先行，出，背水陳。

translations.literal: ' Xin then made 10,000 men go first, exit the pass, and form a battle line with their backs to the water.
translations.idiomatic: ' Xin sent 10,000 men ahead, out through the pass, to form up with their backs to the river.

sentences.zh: 趙軍望見而大笑。

translations.literal: The Zhao army saw this and laughed loudly.
translations.idiomatic: The Zhao troops spotted this and burst out laughing.

sentences.zh: 平旦，信建大將之旗鼓，鼓行出井陘口，趙開壁擊之，大戰良久。

translations.literal: At dawn, Xin raised the supreme commander's banners and drums, beat the drums and marched out of Jingxing pass mouth. Zhao opened their fortifications and attacked, fighting a great battle for a long time.
translations.idiomatic: At daybreak, Xin unfurled his commander's banners and beat the war drums as they marched from the Jingxing pass. Zhao sallied from their fortifications and attacked fiercely, battling intensely for hours.

sentences.zh: 於是信、張耳詳棄鼓旗，走水上軍。

translations.literal: Thereupon Xin and Zhang Er pretended to abandon their banners and drums, fleeing toward the river troops.
translations.idiomatic: Then Xin and Zhang Er feigned panic, abandoning their banners and drums as they fled toward the river position.

sentences.zh: 水上軍開入之，復疾戰。

translations.literal: The river troops opened their ranks to let them in, then fought fiercely again.
translations.idiomatic: The troops by the river opened their lines to admit them, then resumed fighting with renewed ferocity.

sentences.zh: 趙果空壁爭漢鼓旗，逐韓信、張耳。

translations.literal: Zhao indeed emptied their fortifications to contend for Han's banners and drums, pursuing Han Xin and Zhang Er.
translations.idiomatic: As predicted, Zhao abandoned their fortifications to seize Han's banners and drums, chasing after Han Xin and Zhang Er.

sentences.zh: 韓信、張耳已入水上軍，軍皆殊死戰，不可敗。

translations.literal: Han Xin and Zhang Er had already entered the river troops. The army all fought desperately to the death, and could not be defeated.
translations.idiomatic: Now safely within the river position with Han Xin and Zhang Er, the troops fought with suicidal determination and proved invincible.

sentences.zh: 信所出奇兵二千騎，共候趙空壁逐利，則馳入趙壁，皆拔趙旗，立漢赤幟二千。

translations.literal: Xin's surprise troops of 2,000 cavalry together waited for Zhao to empty their fortifications and pursue advantage, then galloped into Zhao's camp, all pulled down Zhao's banners, and raised 2,000 Han red banners.
translations.idiomatic: Xin's elite cavalry of 2,000 waited until Zhao abandoned their camp in pursuit, then charged in, tore down all Zhao banners, and planted 2,000 Han red flags.

sentences.zh: 趙軍已不勝，不能得信等，欲還歸壁，壁皆漢赤幟，而大驚，以為漢皆已得趙王將矣，兵遂亂，遁走，趙將雖斬之，不能禁也。

translations.literal: The Zhao army was already not victorious, could not catch Xin and the others, wished to return to their fortifications. The fortifications were all Han red banners, and they were greatly alarmed, thinking that Han had already captured all the Zhao king's generals. The troops then became chaotic, fleeing in rout. Though the Zhao generals executed them, they could not stop it.
translations.idiomatic: The Zhao army was already losing and couldn't catch Xin and his men. As they tried to retreat to their camp, they saw nothing but Han red flags flying—and panicked, convinced that Han had captured all their generals. Chaos erupted, troops fled in wild disorder. Even executing soldiers couldn't stop the rout.

sentences.zh: 於是漢兵夾擊，大破虜趙軍，斬成安君泜水上，禽趙王歇。

translations.literal: Thereupon Han troops attacked from both flanks, greatly defeated and captured the Zhao army, executed Lord Cheng'an on the Zhi River, and seized King Zhao Xie.
translations.idiomatic: The Han forces then launched a pincer attack, crushing and capturing the Zhao army. Chen Yu was executed on the Zhi River, and King Xie of Zhao was taken prisoner.

sentences.zh: 信乃令軍中毋殺廣武君，有能生得者購千金。

translations.literal: Xin then ordered the army not to kill Lord Guangwu. Whoever could capture him alive would receive a reward of a thousand jin.
translations.idiomatic: Xin commanded his troops not to kill Lord Guangwu, offering a thousand jin reward for anyone who captured him alive.

sentences.zh: 於是有縛廣武君而致戲下者，信乃解其縛，東鄉坐，西鄉對，師事之。

translations.literal: Thereupon there was one who bound Lord Guangwu and brought him to Xin's tent. Xin then loosened his bonds, seated him facing east, sat facing west opposite him, and treated him as a teacher.
translations.idiomatic: Soon someone captured Lord Guangwu and brought him bound to Xin's tent. Xin freed him from his bonds, seated him in the honored eastern position, sat facing west opposite him, and treated him as his master.

sentences.zh: 諸將效首虜，

translations.literal: The various generals presented the heads and captives,
translations.idiomatic: The generals presented their trophies of heads and prisoners,

translations.literal: (rest)
translations.idiomatic: (rest)

sentences.zh: 畢賀，因問信曰：「兵法右倍山陵，前左水澤，今者將軍令臣等反背水陳，曰破趙會食，臣等不服。

translations.literal: Finished congratulating, they then asked Xin: 'Military doctrine says place hills and mountains to the right, water and marshes to the front and left. Now the General ordered us to form with our backs to the water in reverse, saying we would defeat Zhao and gather to eat. We ministers did not understand.
translations.idiomatic: After the congratulations, they asked Xin: 'Military manuals say to position mountains on your right flank, water and marshes in front and to your left. But you ordered us to form up with our backs to the river—backwards from doctrine—and promised we'd defeat Zhao and dine together. We didn't get it.

sentences.zh: 然竟以勝，此何術也？

translations.literal: Yet in the end we won with it. What is this strategy?
translations.idiomatic: And yet we won. What was the secret to this tactic?

sentences.zh: 」信曰：「此在兵法，顧諸君不察耳。

translations.literal: ' Xin said: 'This is in the military law, it's just that you gentlemen did not examine it carefully.
translations.idiomatic: ' Xin replied: 'This is right there in the military classics—you gentlemen just didn't look closely enough.

sentences.zh: 兵法不曰『陷之死地而後生，置之亡地而後存』？

translations.literal: Does not military doctrine say 'Place them in death ground and then they live, put them in doomed ground and then they survive'?
translations.idiomatic: Doesn't military doctrine say 'Drive them into deadly peril and they will fight to live, place them in hopeless straits and they will survive'?

sentences.zh: 且信非得素拊循士大夫也，此所謂『驅市人而戰之』，其勢非置之死地，使人人自為戰；

translations.literal: Moreover, Xin did not obtain troops who were long accustomed to being caressed and governed. This is called 'driving marketplace people to fight'. The situation requires placing them in death ground, making each man fight for himself;
translations.idiomatic: Besides, I don't command well-trained veterans who've been properly led. These are what you call 'driving civilians to battle'. Under these circumstances, you must put them in mortal danger so every man fights desperately for his own life;

sentences.zh: 今予之生地，皆走，寧尚可得而用之乎！

translations.literal: Now if given living ground, they would all flee. How could they still be obtained and used!
translations.idiomatic: If I gave them any hope of escape, they'd all desert. How could I possibly use them then!

sentences.zh: 」諸將皆服曰：「善。

translations.literal: ' All the generals were convinced, saying: 'Excellent.
translations.idiomatic: ' All the generals were persuaded: 'Brilliant.

sentences.zh: 非臣所及也。」

translations.literal: It is not something we ministers can match.'
translations.idiomatic: This surpasses anything we could achieve.'

sentences.zh: 於是信問廣武君曰：「仆欲北攻燕，東伐齊，何若而有功？

translations.literal: Thereupon Xin asked Lord Guangwu: 'I wish to attack Yan to the north and Qi to the east. How can I achieve success?
translations.idiomatic: Then Xin asked Lord Guangwu: 'I plan to strike north at Yan and east at Qi. What strategy will bring victory?

sentences.zh: 」廣武君辭謝曰：「臣聞敗軍之將，不可以言勇，亡國之大夫，不可以圖存。

translations.literal: ' Lord Guangwu declined and said: 'I have heard that a general of defeated armies cannot speak of courage, a minister of a perished state cannot plan for survival.
translations.idiomatic: ' Lord Guangwu politely refused: 'As they say, a defeated general can't advise on bravery, and a minister of a fallen state can't plan for revival.

sentences.zh: 今臣敗亡之虜，何足以權大事乎！

translations.literal: Now I am a captive of defeat and ruin. How can I be sufficient to deliberate on great matters!
translations.idiomatic: Now I am just a prisoner from a lost cause. How can I possibly advise on matters of great importance!

sentences.zh: 」信曰：「仆聞之，百里奚居虞而虞亡，在秦而秦霸，非愚於虞而智於秦也，用與不用，聽與不聽也。

translations.literal: ' Xin said: 'I have heard that Bai Li Xi served Yu and Yu perished, served Qin and Qin became hegemon. It was not that he was foolish in Yu and wise in Qin. It was whether he was employed or not, listened to or not.
translations.idiomatic: ' Xin replied: 'I've heard that when Bai Li Xi served Yu, Yu fell; when he served Qin, Qin became hegemon. He wasn't stupid in Yu and smart in Qin—it was simply a matter of whether his advice was heeded or ignored.

sentences.zh: 誠令成安君聽足下計，若信者亦已為禽矣。

translations.literal: Truly if Lord Cheng'an had listened to Your Lordship's plan, one like me would already have been captured.
translations.idiomatic: If Lord Cheng'an had followed your advice, someone like me would already be a prisoner.

sentences.zh: 以不用足下，故信得侍耳。

translations.literal: Because he did not use Your Lordship, therefore I, Xin, got to serve.
translations.idiomatic: Because he rejected your advice, I got the chance to serve instead.

sentences.zh: 」因固問曰：「仆委心歸計，願足下勿辭。

translations.literal: ' He then firmly asked: 'I wholeheartedly submit to your plan. I wish Your Lordship not to decline.
translations.idiomatic: ' He pressed again: 'I surrender my judgment completely to yours. Please don't refuse to advise me.

sentences.zh: 」廣武君曰：「臣聞智者千慮，必有一失；

translations.literal: ' Lord Guangwu said: 'I have heard that the wise in a thousand considerations must have one mistake;
translations.idiomatic: ' Lord Guangwu replied: 'As they say, even the wisest man makes mistakes in his thousand calculations;

sentences.zh: 愚者千慮，必有一得。

translations.literal: the foolish in a thousand considerations must have one gain.
translations.idiomatic: even fools hit on the right answer once in a thousand tries.

sentences.zh: 故曰『狂夫之言，聖人擇焉』。

translations.literal: Therefore it is said 'From the madman's words, the sage selects.'
translations.idiomatic: That's why they say 'Sages pick the good ideas from madmen's ravings.'

sentences.zh: 顧恐臣計未必足用，願效愚忠。

translations.literal: But I fear my plan may not be sufficient. I wish to offer my foolish loyalty.
translations.idiomatic: Though I worry my strategy may not suffice, I offer it with the best of intentions.

sentences.zh: 夫成安君有百戰百勝之計，一旦而失之，軍敗鄗下，身死泜上。

translations.literal: Now Lord Cheng'an had strategies of a hundred battles a hundred victories. In one moment he lost them, army defeated at Xiang, body dead on the Zhi.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Cheng'an had strategies that won a hundred battles out of a hundred. But he lost just once—his army crushed at Xiang, his body left on the Zhi River.

sentences.zh: 今將軍涉西河，虜魏王，禽夏說閼與，一舉而下井陘，不終朝破趙二十萬眾，誅成安君。

translations.literal: Now the General forded the Xishui, captured the King of Wei, seized Xia Yue at Yanmen, in one action descended Jingxing, in less than a morning broke Zhao's 200,000 multitude, executed Lord Cheng'an.
translations.idiomatic: Now the General has crossed the Yellow River, captured the King of Wei, taken Xia Yue at Yanmen, conquered Jingxing in a single campaign, crushed Zhao's 200,000 host in less than a morning, and executed Lord Cheng'an.

sentences.zh: 名聞海內，威震天下，農夫莫不輟耕釋耒，褕衣甘食，傾耳以待命者。

translations.literal: Name heard within the seas, might shaking the world, farmers none do not stop plowing and release their plowshares, don fine clothes and sweet food, incline their ears waiting for commands.
translations.idiomatic: Your fame resounds throughout the empire, your might shakes the world. Farmers everywhere have abandoned their plows for fine robes and rich food, straining to hear your orders.

sentences.zh: 若此，將軍之所長也。

translations.literal: Like this, this is the General's strength.
translations.idiomatic: This is where your true strength lies, General.

sentences.zh: 然而眾勞卒罷，其實難用。

translations.literal: However, the multitude is weary and the troops exhausted; in reality they are difficult to use.
translations.idiomatic: However, the troops are tired and worn out; they're actually hard to deploy effectively.

sentences.zh: 今將軍欲舉倦獘之兵，頓之燕堅城之下，欲戰恐久力不能拔，情見勢屈，曠日糧竭，而弱燕不服，齊必距境以自彊也。

translations.literal: Now the General wishes to raise weary and foundered troops, station them beneath Yan's strong cities. If you desire to fight, you fear prolonged effort cannot take them. Feelings exposed and momentum weakened, days prolonged and grain exhausted, yet weak Yan will not submit. Qi will certainly guard its borders to strengthen itself.
translations.idiomatic: Now if you mobilize these tired and battered troops and camp them under Yan's formidable walls, you'll fear a long siege you can't win. Your vulnerability exposed and momentum lost, time dragging on and supplies running out—yet weak Yan won't surrender. Qi will certainly fortify its borders and grow stronger.

sentences.zh: 燕齊相持而不下，則劉項之權未有所分也。

translations.literal: If Yan and Qi confront each other and do not fall, then Liu and Xiang's authority will not yet be divided.
translations.idiomatic: If Yan and Qi deadlock without either falling, then the balance of power between Liu and Xiang remains undecided.

sentences.zh: 若此者，將軍所短也。

translations.literal: Like this, this is the General's shortcoming.
translations.idiomatic: This would be your weakness, General.

sentences.zh: 臣愚，竊以為亦過矣。

translations.literal: I am foolish, but privately think this is also a mistake.
translations.idiomatic: Though I am foolish, I secretly believe this would also be an error.

sentences.zh: 故善用兵者不以短擊長，而以長擊短。

translations.literal: Therefore good users of troops do not strike long with short, but strike short with long.
translations.idiomatic: Therefore skilled generals don't attack others' strengths with their own weaknesses—they attack others' weaknesses with their own strengths.

sentences.zh: 」韓信曰：「然則何由？

translations.literal: ' Han Xin said: 'Then by what means?
translations.idiomatic: ' Han Xin asked: 'Then what should I do?

sentences.zh: 」廣武君對曰：「方今為將軍計，莫如案甲休兵，鎮趙撫其孤，百里之內，牛酒日至，以饗士大夫醳兵，北首燕路，而後遣辯士奉咫尺之書，暴其所長於燕，燕必不敢不聽從。

translations.literal: ' Lord Guangwu replied: 'For the General's present plan, nothing is better than sheathing armor and resting troops, pacifying Zhao and comforting its orphans. Within a hundred li, oxen and wine arrive daily to feast the gentlemen and relax the troops. Face north toward Yan's road, then afterward send eloquent scholars bearing short letters, exposing your strengths to Yan. Yan will certainly dare not but obey.
translations.idiomatic: ' Lord Guangwu replied: 'For your current strategy, nothing beats resting your troops and sheathing your swords. Stabilize Zhao and care for its war orphans. Within a hundred li, let oxen and wine arrive daily to feast your officers and relax your soldiers. Turn your attention north toward Yan, then send skilled diplomats with brief letters highlighting your advantages. Yan will have no choice but to submit.

sentences.zh: 燕已從，使諠言者東告齊，齊必從風而服，雖有智者，亦不知為齊計矣。

translations.literal: Once Yan has followed, send rumormongers east to tell Qi. Qi will certainly follow the wind and submit. Though there be wise ones, they also will not know to plan for Qi.
translations.idiomatic: Once Yan submits, dispatch agents to spread rumors east to Qi. Qi will follow suit and surrender. Even their wisest counselors won't know how to save Qi.

sentences.zh: 如是，則天下事皆可圖也。

translations.literal: Like this, then all under heaven's affairs can all be planned for.
translations.idiomatic: In this way, you can plan for everything under heaven.

sentences.zh: 兵固有先聲而後實者，此之謂也。

translations.literal: Troops certainly have those who put reputation first and reality after; this is what is called that.
translations.idiomatic: Military strategy sometimes builds reputation first, then follows with action—this is exactly what I mean.

sentences.zh: 」韓信曰：「善。

translations.literal: ' Han Xin said: 'Good.
translations.idiomatic: ' Han Xin said: 'Excellent.

sentences.zh: 」從其策，發使使燕，燕從風而靡。

translations.literal: ' He followed the plan, dispatched envoys to Yan. Yan followed the wind and yielded.
translations.idiomatic: ' He adopted the strategy, sent diplomats to Yan. Yan surrendered immediately.

sentences.zh: 乃遣使報漢，因請立張耳為趙王，以鎮撫其國。

translations.literal: Thereupon he dispatched envoys to report to Han, and by the way requested to establish Zhang Er as King of Zhao, to pacify and soothe its state.
translations.idiomatic: He sent messengers to report to Han, and requested that Zhang Er be made King of Zhao to stabilize and govern the territory.

sentences.zh: 漢王許之，乃立張耳為趙王。

translations.literal: The Han king permitted it, thereupon established Zhang Er as King of Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king agreed, and Zhang Er was made King of Zhao.

sentences.zh: 楚數使奇兵渡河擊趙，趙王耳、韓信往來救趙，因行定趙城邑，發兵詣漢。

translations.literal: Chu repeatedly sent surprise troops across the river to attack Zhao. King Zhao Er and Han Xin went back and forth rescuing Zhao. By this means they marched and pacified Zhao's cities and towns, sent troops to Han.
translations.idiomatic: Chu kept sending elite troops across the Yellow River to raid Zhao. King Zhao Zhang Er and Han Xin shuttled back and forth defending Zhao, and in the process pacified Zhao's cities and towns, sending troops to reinforce Han.

sentences.zh: 楚方急圍漢王於滎陽，漢王南出，之宛、葉閒，得黥布，走入成皋，楚又復急圍之。

translations.literal: Chu was urgently besieging the Han king at Xingyang. The Han king went south out, went between Wan and Ye, obtained Ying Bu, fled into Chenggao. Chu again urgently besieged him.
translations.idiomatic: Chu was laying siege to the Han king at Xingyang. The Han king broke out to the south, passed between Wan and Ye, recruited Ying Bu, and fled into Chenggao. Chu besieged him there again.

sentences.zh: 六月，漢王出成皋，東渡河，獨與滕公俱，從張耳軍修武。

translations.literal: In the sixth month, the Han king exited Chenggao, crossed the river east, alone with Duke Teng together, went to Zhang Er's army at Xiuwu.
translations.idiomatic: In the sixth month, the Han king escaped from Chenggao, crossed the Yellow River east, accompanied only by Duke Teng, and went to Zhang Er's army at Xiuwu.

sentences.zh: 至，宿傳舍。

translations.literal: Upon arrival, he lodged at the post station.
translations.idiomatic: Upon arrival, he stayed at the government inn.

sentences.zh: 晨自稱漢使，馳入趙壁。

translations.literal: In the morning he claimed to be a Han envoy, galloped into Zhao's fortifications.
translations.idiomatic: In the morning he posed as a Han messenger and charged into Zhao's camp.

sentences.zh: 張耳、韓信未起，即其臥內上奪其印符，以麾召諸將，易置之。

translations.literal: Zhang Er and Han Xin had not yet risen. Right in their sleeping quarters he seized their seals and tallies from above, used the banner to summon the various generals, changed their positions.
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Er and Han Xin were still asleep. Liu Bang went straight into their quarters, took their seals and command tallies, and used the banner to summon the generals and reassign them.

sentences.zh: 信、耳起，乃知漢王來，大驚。

translations.literal: Xin and Er arose, then knew the Han king had come, greatly astonished.
translations.idiomatic: Xin and Zhang Er woke up and discovered the Han king had arrived—they were stunned.

sentences.zh: 漢王奪兩人軍，即令張耳備守趙地。

translations.literal: The Han king seized the two men's armies, immediately ordered Zhang Er to prepare to defend Zhao territory.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king took command of both men's armies and immediately ordered Zhang Er to prepare defenses for Zhao territory.

sentences.zh: 拜韓信為相國，收趙兵未發者擊齊。

translations.literal: Enfeoffed Han Xin as Prime Minister, gathered Zhao troops not yet dispatched to attack Qi.
translations.idiomatic: He appointed Han Xin as Prime Minister and gathered the remaining Zhao troops to attack Qi.

sentences.zh: 信引兵東，未渡平原，聞漢王使酈食其已說下齊，韓信欲止。

translations.literal: Xin led troops east, had not yet crossed Pingyuan, heard that the Han king had sent Li Yiji who had already persuaded Qi to submit. Han Xin wished to stop.
translations.idiomatic: Xin marched his army east but hadn't crossed Pingyuan Plain when he heard the Han king had sent Li Yiji who had already talked Qi into surrendering. Han Xin wanted to halt his advance.

sentences.zh: 范陽辯士蒯通說信曰：「將軍受詔擊齊，而漢獨發閒使下齊，寧有詔止將軍乎？

translations.literal: The eloquent scholar Kuai Tong from Fanyang advised Xin, saying: 'The General received the imperial decree to attack Qi, yet Han alone sent a secret envoy to conquer Qi. Could there be an imperial decree stopping the General?
translations.idiomatic: The skilled debater Kuai Tong from Fanyang counseled Xin: 'You were ordered by imperial decree to attack Qi, yet Han sent a private envoy to subdue Qi. Is there any imperial order telling you to stop?

sentences.zh: 何以得毋行也！

translations.literal: Why should you not advance!
translations.idiomatic: Why should you hold back!

sentences.zh: 且酈生一士，伏軾掉三寸之舌，下齊七十餘城，將軍將數萬眾，歲餘乃下趙五十餘，為將數歲，反不如一豎儒之功乎？

translations.literal: Moreover, Li Sheng is but one scholar, crouching on his carriage, waggling his three-inch tongue, conquered Qi's seventy-odd cities. The General commands several tens of thousands of multitudes, more than a year then conquered Zhao's fifty-odd cities. Having been a general for several years, could it be that he is instead inferior to one lowly Confucian scholar's achievement?
translations.idiomatic: Besides, Li Yiji is just one scholar who rode in his carriage and wagged his three-inch tongue to take over seventy Qi cities. You command tens of thousands of troops, took more than a year to conquer over fifty Zhao cities. After being a general for years, are you really going to be outdone by some pedantic scholar?

sentences.zh: 」於是信然之，從其計，遂渡河。

translations.literal: ' Thereupon Xin considered it so, followed his plan, thereupon crossed the river.
translations.idiomatic: ' Xin was convinced and adopted Kuai Tong's plan, then crossed the Yellow River.

sentences.zh: 齊已聽酈生，即留縱酒，罷備漢守御。

translations.literal: Qi had already listened to Li Sheng, immediately detained him and indulged in wine, dismissed the preparations for Han defense.
translations.idiomatic: Qi had already accepted Li Yiji's terms, so they detained him and threw drinking parties, abandoning all defenses against Han.

sentences.zh: 信因襲齊歷下軍，遂至臨菑。

translations.literal: Xin then attacked Qi's Lixia army by surprise, thereupon reached Linzi.
translations.idiomatic: Xin launched a surprise attack on Qi's Lixia garrison, then reached Linzi.

sentences.zh: 齊王田廣以酈生賣己，乃亨之，而走高密，使使之楚請救。

translations.literal: Qi King Tian Guang considered Li Sheng had betrayed him, thereupon boiled him, and fled to Gaomi, dispatched envoys to Chu requesting rescue.
translations.idiomatic: Qi King Tian Guang thought Li Yiji had betrayed him, so he had him boiled alive, then fled to Gaomi and sent envoys to Chu begging for help.

sentences.zh: 韓信已定臨菑，遂東追廣至高密西。

translations.literal: Han Xin had already pacified Linzi, thereupon pursued east to Guang west of Gaomi.
translations.idiomatic: Han Xin secured Linzi, then chased east after Guang, reaching west of Gaomi.

sentences.zh: 楚亦使龍且將，號稱二十萬，救齊。

translations.literal: Chu also sent Long Ju as general, claiming 200,000, to rescue Qi.
translations.idiomatic: Chu dispatched General Long Ju with a force claiming 200,000 troops to save Qi.

sentences.zh: 齊王廣、龍且并軍與信戰，未合。

translations.literal: Qi King Guang and Long Ju combined their armies to fight Xin, had not yet engaged.
translations.idiomatic: Qi King Guang and Long Ju merged their forces to battle Xin, but hadn't clashed yet.

sentences.zh: 人或說龍且曰：「漢兵遠鬬窮戰，其鋒不可當。

translations.literal: Someone advised Long Ju, saying: 'Han troops fight far from home in desperate battle, their sharpness cannot be withstood.
translations.idiomatic: Someone counseled Long Ju: 'Han troops are fighting far from home in a do-or-die struggle—their momentum is unstoppable.

sentences.zh: 齊、楚自居其地戰，兵易敗散。

translations.literal: Qi and Chu fight defending their own territory, troops easily defeated and scattered.
translations.idiomatic: Qi and Chu are fighting to defend their home ground—troops in that situation are prone to rout.

sentences.zh: 不如深壁，令齊王使其信臣招所亡城，亡城聞其王在，楚來救，必反漢。

translations.literal: Better to fortify deeply, have the Qi king send his trusted ministers to summon the lost cities. The lost cities hearing their king is there, Chu comes to rescue, will certainly turn against Han.
translations.idiomatic: Better to fortify strongly and let the Qi king send his trusted officials to reclaim the lost cities. When the fallen cities learn their king still lives and Chu comes to help, they'll surely revolt against Han.

sentences.zh: 漢兵二千里客居，齊城皆反之，其勢無所得食，可無戰而降也。

translations.literal: Han troops reside as guests 2,000 li away, Qi cities all turn against them, their situation has nothing to obtain food, can surrender without battle.
translations.idiomatic: Han troops are 2,000 li from home as strangers in a hostile land. With Qi cities turning against them, they'll starve. They can be forced to surrender without fighting.

sentences.zh: 」龍且曰：「吾平生知韓信為人，易與耳。

translations.literal: ' Long Ju said: 'All my life I have known Han Xin's character, he is easy to deal with.
translations.idiomatic: ' Long Ju said: 'I've known Han Xin all my life—he's an easy opponent.

sentences.zh: 且夫救齊不戰而降之，吾何功？

translations.literal: Moreover, saving Qi without battle and making it surrender, what merit do I have?
translations.idiomatic: Besides, if I save Qi without fighting and they just surrender, where's my glory?

sentences.zh: 今戰而勝之，齊之半可得，何為止！

translations.literal: Now fight and defeat them, half of Qi can be obtained, why stop!
translations.idiomatic: Now if we fight and win, I can get half of Qi—why hold back!

sentences.zh: 」遂戰，與信夾濰水陳。

translations.literal: ' Thereupon they fought, formed lines with Xin across the Wei River.
translations.idiomatic: ' So they engaged, drawing up battle lines with Xin across the Wei River.

sentences.zh: 韓信乃夜令人為萬餘囊，滿盛沙，壅水上流，引軍半渡，擊龍且，詳不勝，還走。

translations.literal: Han Xin then at night had men make over 10,000 bags, filled full with sand, dammed the river upstream, led the army half across, attacked Long Ju, pretended not to win, returned and fled.
translations.idiomatic: Han Xin had his men make over 10,000 sandbags that night and dam the river upstream. He led half his army across, attacked Long Ju, then feigned defeat and retreated.

sentences.zh: 龍且果喜曰：「固知信怯也。

translations.literal: Long Ju indeed was pleased, saying: 'I knew all along that Xin was cowardly.
translations.idiomatic: Long Ju was delighted: 'I knew Xin was a coward all along.

sentences.zh: 」遂追信渡水。

translations.literal: ' Thereupon he pursued Xin across the water.
translations.idiomatic: ' So he chased Xin across the river.

sentences.zh: 信使人決壅囊，水大至。

translations.literal: Xin had men break open the damming bags, great waters arrived.
translations.idiomatic: Xin ordered his men to breach the sandbag dam, unleashing a torrent of water.

sentences.zh: 龍且軍大半不得渡，即急擊，殺龍且。

translations.literal: Long Ju's army's great half could not cross, immediately attacked fiercely, killed Long Ju.
translations.idiomatic: Most of Long Ju's army couldn't cross the rising floodwaters. Han Xin launched a furious counterattack and killed Long Ju.

sentences.zh: 龍且水東軍散走，齊王廣亡去。

translations.literal: Long Ju's east-of-water army scattered and fled, Qi King Guang fled away.
translations.idiomatic: Long Ju's forces east of the river panicked and fled in all directions. Qi King Guang escaped.

sentences.zh: 信遂追北至城陽，皆虜楚卒。

translations.literal: Xin thereupon pursued the defeated north to Chengyang, all captured Chu troops.
translations.idiomatic: Xin pursued the fleeing enemy north to Chengyang and captured all the Chu soldiers.

sentences.zh: 漢四年，遂皆降平齊。

translations.literal: Han fourth year, thereupon all surrendered and pacified Qi.
translations.idiomatic: In the fourth year of Han, Qi was completely subdued and pacified.

sentences.zh: 使人言漢王曰：「齊偽詐多變，反覆之國也，南邊楚，不為假王以鎮之，其勢不定。

translations.literal: Sent men to speak to the Han king, saying: 'Qi is deceitful and changeable, a country of reversals. Borders Chu to the south; if not made acting king to pacify it, the situation will not be stable.
translations.idiomatic: He sent messengers to tell the Han king: 'Qi is treacherous and fickle, prone to double-crossing. It borders Chu to the south. Without an acting king to stabilize it, the situation will remain unstable.

sentences.zh: 願為假王便。

translations.literal: Wish to be acting king for convenience.
translations.idiomatic: I request to be made acting king for administrative convenience.

sentences.zh: 」當是時，楚方急圍漢王於滎陽，韓信使者至，發書，漢王大怒，罵曰：「吾困於此，旦暮望若來佐我，乃欲自立為王！

translations.literal: ' At this time, Chu was urgently besieging the Han king at Xingyang. Han Xin's messenger arrived, opened the letter. The Han king was greatly angered, cursed saying: 'I am trapped here, morning and evening hope you will come assist me, yet you want to establish yourself as king!
translations.idiomatic: ' Just then, Chu was laying siege to the Han king at Xingyang. When Han Xin's messenger arrived and delivered the letter, the Han king flew into a rage, cursing: 'I'm trapped here, waiting every moment for you to come help me, and you want to crown yourself king!

sentences.zh: 」張良、陳平躡漢王足，因附耳語曰：「漢方不利，寧能禁信之王乎？

translations.literal: ' Zhang Liang and Chen Ping stepped on the Han king's foot, then attached their ears and whispered: 'Han is presently in disadvantage, how can we prohibit Xin from being king?
translations.idiomatic: ' Zhang Liang and Chen Ping nudged the Han king's foot, then leaned in and whispered: 'Han is in a bad position right now. How can we stop Xin from becoming king?

sentences.zh: 不如因而立，善遇之，使自為守。

translations.literal: Better to take advantage and establish him, treat him well, make him defend for himself.
translations.idiomatic: Better to go along with it and make him king, treat him generously, and let him defend his own territory.

sentences.zh: 不然，變生。

translations.literal: If not, change arises.
translations.idiomatic: Otherwise, trouble will brew.

sentences.zh: 」漢王亦悟，因復罵曰：「大丈夫定諸侯，即為真王耳，何以假為！

translations.literal: ' The Han king also awakened, thereupon again cursed saying: 'A great man pacifies the feudal lords, then is true king. Why make acting!
translations.idiomatic: ' The Han king came to his senses, then cursed again: 'A real man conquers the lords and becomes a true king. Why settle for acting king!

sentences.zh: 」乃遣張良往立信為齊王，徵其兵擊楚。

translations.literal: ' Thereupon dispatched Zhang Liang to go establish Xin as King of Qi, summoned his troops to attack Chu.
translations.idiomatic: ' So he sent Zhang Liang to make Han Xin King of Qi and summon his armies to attack Chu.

sentences.zh: 楚已亡龍且，項王恐，使盱眙人武涉往說齊王信曰：「天下共苦秦久矣，相與力擊秦。

translations.literal: Chu had already lost Long Ju, King Xiang feared, sent the Xuyi man Wu She to go persuade Qi King Xin, saying: 'The world together suffered Qin for long, mutually exerted strength to attack Qin.
translations.idiomatic: After losing Long Ju, Xiang Yu grew fearful and sent Wu She from Xuyi to persuade King Xin of Qi: 'The whole world suffered under Qin for so long, and we joined forces to overthrow them.

sentences.zh: 秦已破，計功割地，分土而王之，以休士卒。

translations.literal: Qin had already been broken, calculated merit and divided territory, apportioned land and made them kings, in order to rest the troops.
translations.idiomatic: After Qin fell, they divided up the territory according to merit and made kings of the various regions to give the troops a rest.

sentences.zh: 今漢王復興兵而東，侵人之分，奪人之地，已破三秦，引兵出關，收諸侯之兵以東擊楚，其意非盡吞天下者不休，其不知厭足如是甚也。

translations.literal: Now the Han king again raises troops and goes east, invades others' domains, seizes others' lands. Already broken the three Qin, led troops out the pass, gathered the feudal lords' troops to east attack Chu. His intent is not to swallow all under heaven completely will not rest, his not knowing satisfaction is so extreme.
translations.idiomatic: Now the Han king has raised troops again and marched east, invading others' territories and seizing their lands. He's already conquered the three Qin regions, led his army out of the passes, gathered the other lords' troops, and is attacking Chu to the east. His ambition is to swallow the entire world—he won't stop until he has it all. His greed knows no bounds.

sentences.zh: 且漢王不可必，身居項王掌握中數矣，項王憐而活之，然得脫，輒倍約，復擊項王，其不可親信如此。

translations.literal: Moreover, the Han king cannot be depended on. His person has dwelt in King Xiang's grasp several times. King Xiang pitied and spared him, yet once he escaped, he immediately broke agreements and again attacked King Xiang. His inability to be intimately trusted is like this.
translations.idiomatic: Besides, the Han king can't be trusted. Xiang Yu has had him completely at his mercy several times. Xiang Yu took pity and spared him, but as soon as he got free, Liu Bang broke their agreements and attacked Xiang Yu again. That's how unreliable he is.

sentences.zh: 今足下雖自以與漢王為厚交，為之盡力用兵，終為之所禽矣。

translations.literal: Now though Your Lordship considers himself to have thick friendship with the Han king, exerts strength for him using troops, in the end will be captured by him.
translations.idiomatic: Even though you consider yourself Liu Bang's close friend and fight loyally for him, in the end he'll turn on you and have you captured.

sentences.zh: 足下所以得須臾至今者，以項王尚存也。

translations.literal: Your Lordship's reason for obtaining a moment until now is that King Xiang still exists.
translations.idiomatic: The only reason you've survived this long is because Xiang Yu is still alive.

sentences.zh: 當今二王之事，權在足下。

translations.literal: The present two kings' affair, authority is in Your Lordship.
translations.idiomatic: The fate of these two kings lies entirely in your hands.

sentences.zh: 足下右投則漢王勝，左投則項王勝。

translations.literal: Your Lordship right throws then Han king wins, left throws then King Xiang wins.
translations.idiomatic: If you throw your support to Liu Bang, he wins; if you throw it to Xiang Yu, he wins.

sentences.zh: 項王今日亡，則次取足下。

translations.literal: King Xiang today perishes, then next takes Your Lordship.
translations.idiomatic: Once Xiang Yu is gone, Liu Bang will come after you next.

sentences.zh: 足下與項王有故，何不反漢與楚連和，參分天下王之？

translations.literal: Your Lordship and King Xiang have old acquaintance, why not rebel against Han and ally with Chu, divide the world three ways and be kings?
translations.idiomatic: You and Xiang Yu go way back—why not defect from Han, ally with Chu, and divide the world three ways as kings?

sentences.zh: 今釋此時，而自必於漢以擊楚，且為智者固若此乎！

translations.literal: Now release this time, and obligate yourself to Han to attack Chu, moreover is this the way of a wise person indeed!
translations.idiomatic: To let this golden opportunity slip by and commit yourself to fighting Chu for Han—is this really the action of a wise man?

sentences.zh: 」韓信謝曰：「臣事項王，官不過郎中，位不過執戟，言不聽，畫不用，故倍楚而歸漢。

translations.literal: ' Han Xin thanked him, saying: 'I served King Xiang, office no more than palace attendant, position no more than halberd holder. Words not listened to, plans not used, therefore I abandoned Chu and returned to Han.
translations.idiomatic: ' Han Xin thanked him politely: 'I served under Xiang Yu, but my rank never rose above palace attendant, my position never higher than halberd bearer. My advice went unheard, my strategies unused. That's why I left Chu for Han.

sentences.zh: 漢王授我上將軍印，予我數萬眾，解衣衣我，推食食我，言聽計用，故吾得以至於此。

translations.literal: The Han king gave me the supreme general seal, granted me several tens of thousands of multitude, removed his clothes to clothe me, pushed his food to feed me. Words listened to, plans used, therefore I have been able to reach this point.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king gave me the supreme commander's seal, entrusted me with tens of thousands of troops, shared his own clothes and food with me. He listened to my words and adopted my plans. That's how I've achieved what I have.

sentences.zh: 夫人深親信我，我倍之不祥，雖死不易。

translations.literal: That person deeply befriends and trusts me, I to betray him is inauspicious, though death I will not change.
translations.idiomatic: He treats me with deep friendship and trust. To betray him would bring ill fortune. I won't change even if it costs me my life.

sentences.zh: 幸為信謝項王！」

translations.literal: Fortunate to apologize to King Xiang for Xin!'
translations.idiomatic: Please convey my apologies to King Xiang!'

sentences.zh: 武涉已去，齊人蒯通知天下權在韓信，欲為奇策而感動之，以相人說韓信曰：「仆嘗受相人之術。

translations.literal: Wu She had already gone. The Qi man Kuai Tong knew the world's authority lay in Han Xin, wished to make extraordinary strategy and move him emotionally, used physiognomy to persuade Han Xin, saying: 'I once received the art of physiognomy.
translations.idiomatic: After Wu She left, Kuai Tong of Qi realized that Han Xin held the balance of power in the world. He wanted to devise some extraordinary scheme to sway him, so he used physiognomy to persuade Han Xin: 'I once studied the art of reading faces.

sentences.zh: 」韓信曰：「先生相人何如？

translations.literal: ' Han Xin said: 'How is the Master's physiognomy?
translations.idiomatic: ' Han Xin asked: 'How skilled are you at reading faces, Master?

sentences.zh: 」對曰：「貴賤在於骨法，憂喜在於容色，成敗在於決斷，以此參之，萬不失一。

translations.literal: ' Replied: 'Nobility and baseness lie in bone structure, sorrow and joy lie in complexion, success and failure lie in decisiveness. Using this to examine them, in ten thousand cases not one is missed.
translations.idiomatic: ' He replied: 'Status is revealed in bone structure, emotions in facial coloring, outcomes in decision-making. When I examine people this way, I'm right nine thousand nine hundred ninety-nine times out of ten thousand.

sentences.zh: 」韓信曰：「善。

translations.literal: ' Han Xin said: 'Good.
translations.idiomatic: ' Han Xin said: 'Impressive.

sentences.zh: 先生相寡人何如？

translations.literal: Master, how do you read me?
translations.idiomatic: Master, what do you see in my face?

sentences.zh: 」對曰：「願少閒。

translations.literal: ' Replied: 'I wish a little seclusion.
translations.idiomatic: ' He replied: 'I'd like some privacy, please.

sentences.zh: 」信曰：「左右去矣。

translations.literal: ' Xin said: 'Attendants withdraw.
translations.idiomatic: ' Xin said: 'Everyone leave us.

sentences.zh: 」通曰：「相君之面，不過封侯，又危不安。

translations.literal: ' Tong said: 'Reading Your Lordship's face, no more than enfeoffed as marquis, moreover dangerous and unstable.
translations.idiomatic: ' Tong said: 'From reading your face, you'll be ennobled as a marquis at most, but your position will be precarious and insecure.

sentences.zh: 相君之背，貴乃不可言。

translations.literal: Reading Your Lordship's back, nobility then cannot be spoken.
translations.idiomatic: But reading your back reveals nobility beyond words.

sentences.zh: 」韓信曰：「何謂也？

translations.literal: ' Han Xin said: 'What does this mean?
translations.idiomatic: ' Han Xin asked: 'What do you mean by that?

sentences.zh: 」蒯通曰：「天下初發難也，俊雄豪桀建號壹呼，天下之士雲合霧集，魚鱗襍遝，熛至風起。

translations.literal: ' Kuai Tong said: 'When the world first rose in difficulty, outstanding heroes and bold leaders established titles with one call, the world's scholars gathered like clouds and mist, fish scales mixed together, fire arrives and wind rises.
translations.idiomatic: ' Kuai Tong said: 'When the world first erupted in rebellion, outstanding heroes and bold leaders raised their banners with a single call. Scholars from across the empire gathered like clouds and fog, packed together like fish scales, igniting fires that stirred up winds.

sentences.zh: 當此之時，憂在亡秦而已。

translations.literal: At this time, the worry was only in perishing Qin.
translations.idiomatic: Back then, everyone's only concern was destroying Qin.

sentences.zh: 今楚漢分爭，使天下無罪之人肝膽涂地，父子暴骸骨於中野，不可勝數。

translations.literal: Now Chu and Han divide and contend, causing the world's innocent people liver and gall smeared on earth, fathers and sons expose bones in the wilds, cannot be counted.
translations.idiomatic: Now Chu and Han are locked in civil war, causing countless innocent people to die horribly—livers and gall smeared on the ground, fathers and sons left with exposed bones in the wilderness, beyond counting.

sentences.zh: 楚人起彭城，轉鬬逐北，至於滎陽，乘利席卷，威震天下。

translations.literal: Chu people rose from Pengcheng, transferred battle pursued north, reached Xingyang, rode advantage rolled up like mat, might shook the world.
translations.idiomatic: Chu forces started from Pengcheng, fought their way north in rolling battles until they reached Xingyang. They rode their momentum like a tidal wave, their might shaking the whole world.

sentences.zh: 然兵困於京、索之閒，迫西山而不能進者，三年於此矣。

translations.literal: Yet troops are trapped between Jing and Suo, press against the western mountains and cannot advance, three years at this.
translations.idiomatic: But now their army is bogged down between Jing and Suo Passes, pressed against the western mountains unable to advance—for three years now.

sentences.zh: 漢王將數十萬之眾，距鞏、雒，阻山河之險，一日數戰，無尺寸之功，折北不救，敗滎陽，傷成皋，遂走宛、葉之閒，此所謂智勇俱困者也。

translations.literal: Han king commands several hundred thousand multitude, confronts at Gong and Luo, blocks mountain and river dangers, one day several battles, no inch of achievement, broken north without rescue, defeated at Xingyang, wounded at Chenggao, then fled between Wan and Ye, this is called wisdom and bravery both exhausted.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king commands hundreds of thousands, but he's stuck facing Gong and Luo, blocked by mountains and rivers. They fight several battles a day with no gains, suffer defeat after defeat—routed at Xingyang, mauled at Chenggao, forced to flee between Wan and Ye. This is what you call both wisdom and courage exhausted.

sentences.zh: 夫銳氣挫於險塞，而糧食竭於內府，百姓罷極怨望，容容無所倚。

translations.literal: Now sharp spirit blunted at dangerous passes, and grain exhausted in inner storehouses, common people extremely weary and resentful, floating without anything to rely on.
translations.idiomatic: Both sides have their fighting spirit broken at perilous passes, their granaries emptied, their people utterly exhausted and filled with resentment—adrift with nothing to depend on.

sentences.zh: 以臣料之，其勢非天下之賢聖固不能息天下之禍。

translations.literal: In my minister's estimation, the situation requires that only the world's worthy sages can firmly end the world's calamities.
translations.idiomatic: In my view, only a true sage of the world can put an end to these universal disasters.

sentences.zh: 當今兩主之命縣於足下。

translations.literal: The present two lords' fates hang suspended on Your Lordship.
translations.idiomatic: The lives of these two rulers hang entirely on your decision.

sentences.zh: 足下為漢則漢勝，與楚則楚勝。

translations.literal: Your Lordship aids Han then Han wins, allies with Chu then Chu wins.
